abstract.text: Surgeons need guidance regarding appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) during the COVID-19 pandemic based on scientific evidence rather than availability. The aim of this paper is to inform surgeons of appropriate PPE requirements, and to discuss usage, availability, rationing and future solutions.

Of a total 1329 articles identified, 305 were removed (duplicates etc), and finally, 95 studies met the inclusion criteria. Recommendations made by the WHO regarding the use of PPE in the COVID-19 pandemic have evolved alongside emerging evidence. Medical resources including PPE have been rapidly overwhelmed. There is a global effort to overcome this by combining the most effective use of existing PPE in combination with innovative strategies to produce more. Practical advice on all aspects of PPE are detailed in this systematic review.
Although there is a need to balance limited supplies with staff and patient safety, this should not leave surgeons treating patients with inadequate PPE.

body_text.text: In December 2019 clusters of patients presenting with severe pneumonia of unknown origin were reported in the city of Wuhan, Hubei Provence, China. Epidemiologically these were linked to a seafood market in the city and on January 7, 2020 the causative organism, a novel coronavirus (now termed SARS-CoV-2) was identified 1 . In March 2020 the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared a global pandemic 2 , which has gathered speed across the world despite increasingly more drastic non-pharmacological interventions (NPI's) to limit its spread. With a quarter of the world's population now living under some form of government mandated lockdown, and over three million documented cases worldwide, NPI's are the main public health measure that policymakers are using to reduce viral transmission 3, 4 . Social distancing aims to flatten the curve of new infections, thereby avoiding a surge in demand on health care systems, but these effects may take weeks to months to manifest. Epidemiological modelling has shown that the pandemic could last for 12 to 18 months and that social distancing may need to continue until a vaccine has been developed 3 .

The impact on surgical services of this crisis will be wide ranging 5 . Many thousands of patients worldwide are deprived of surgical access and are waiting to undergo elective and emergency surgical procedures. They will become part of the -second and subsequent waves‖, with undoubted morbidity and mortality as a collateral effect of the COVID-19 pandemic 6,7 . Currently the majority of evidence is of low quality, including case series and observational studies, with heterogenous populations and surgical intervention groups.

Fortunately, global collaborative initiatives have been launched, with the CovidSurg collaborative 8 an excellent example, which aims to give guidance on how to deliver surgical services safely and effectively during the COVID-19 pandemic.

WHO modelling of personal protective equipment (PPE) for healthcare professionals estimates that 89 million medical masks, 76 million gloves, 1.6 million goggles and 30 million gowns are required for the COVID-19 response each month 9 . China is the major producer and supplier of PPE globally and as the infection spread domestically, its exports have come to a halt 10 . A combination of disruption to worldwide supply chains, international travel restrictions, combined with exceptionally high levels of demand, slow release of pandemic stocks as well as confusing and ever changing PPE guidelines has led to a lack of PPE for frontline medical staff 11 , and confusion around when it is needed 12 . This systematic review summarises the SARS-CoV-2 transmission risks for different surgical specialties,
This systematic review was undertaken in accordance with the PRISMA guidelines 14 .
MEDLINE (via PubMed), Embase, and WHO COVID-19 Database were searched.

Newspaper and internet article sources were identified using a media database called Nexis (https://www.lexisnexis.com/en-us/products/nexis.page). The search terms used were There was no restriction on publication type. This search was complemented by an exhaustive review of the bibliography of key articles. Results were restricted to English Language articles.

All studies on the application of PPE in surgery during the COVID-19 pandemic were included. This included articles that reported on potential risks of transmission in surgery, types of PPE, specialty specific risks and guidance. Papers that described PPE not in relation to surgery or COVID-19 were excluded as were non-English papers.

Two authors independently assessed the articles for inclusion and exclusion criteria and extracted data with a third author resolving any differences. The data extraction was independently checked by the senior author. The following baseline data were extracted from each study: first author, year of publication, data collection period, geographical location, surgical specialty. Data were extracted on the sources of transmission in surgery, types of PPE recommended, surgical specialty specific risks and considerations, PPE shortages and rationing.
body_text.section: Data extraction and assessment of study quality

body_text.text: Given the marked heterogeneity in study design and types that have been published during the emerging COVID-19 pandemic, a narrative synthesis was performed according to the Guidance on the Conduct of Narrative Synthesis in Systematic Reviews 15 . Three authors systematically summarized each article using bullet points to document key aspects of each study, focusing specifically on the availability, usage and rationing of PPE in surgery. The senior author identified and grouped common themes, divided larger themes into subthemes, tabulated a combined summary of the paper, and synthesized a common rubric for each theme.

A total of 1329 articles were identified from all literature sources, leaving 1024 for screening of titles and abstracts following removal of duplicates . Ninety-five studies met the inclusion criteria and were included in the narrative synthesis (Figure 1 and Table 1 ).

Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is via particles or droplets containing the virus (>5um, travel <1m) as well as aerosol (smaller particles <5um, travel >1m), via fomites and subsequent direct contact (touching eyes, nose or mouth) 16, 17 . This is recognised to be especially high risk for healthcare professionals performing resuscitation 18 . PPE requirements have largely been defined based on whether a procedure is aerosol generating or not 19 . Although airway procedures such as intubation, extubation and suctioning are widely recognised to generate aerosols, specific aerosol generating surgical procedures have been less well described but are critical to identify during the COVID-19 pandemic in order to guide where extra PPE precaution is indicated ( Table 2) [20] [21] [22] [23] [24] [25] [26] masks represent the gold standard of precaution, able to filter >99% (offering 100 to 10,000 fold protection) compared to 63% (6 fold) for standard surgical masks 49 (Figure 3 ).

Constraints within the NHS have been recognised and both an FFP2 or N95 equivalent respirators offer high levels of protection if fitted well, with a minimum efficiency of 92-98% (offering 100-fold protection) (Figure 4) . Protection using FFP2/3 respirators is reported to last up to 8 hours duration and current guidelines support ‗sessional use' in the care of multiple patients in red zones 50 , whereas protection is reported to last 30 minutes for fluid repellent surgical masks 51 . It is important to note that masks alone are not the panacea and need to be combined with correct fitting via ‗fit tests', avoidance of face/mask touching, regular hand washing and social distancing to minimise transmission 13 .
The current advice from UK surgical professional bodies is summarised in Table 2 .

Emerging evidence highlights that certain subspecialties are at higher risk based on their potential exposure to high viral loads in mucosal membranes of the naso-and oropharynx, Within other specialties there has been a drive to identify high risk procedures and minimise their use where possible 66 . In general surgery laparoscopy and endoscopy should only be performed where there is no alternative and laparotomies carried out wearing full PPE [67] [68] [69] [70] .
Similar changes in guidance have been seen in gynaecology 71, 72 , paediatric surgery 73 , urology 74 , orthopaedics 75, 76 , head and neck cancer 77 and neurosurgery 78 .

In the short history of this pandemic, medical resources have already been rapidly overwhelmed, including personal protective equipment (PPE). In recent days there have been well reported critical shortages of gowns 79 and masks [80] [81] [82] in particular, with famous businesses supporting the national need in addition to other philanthropic donations 83, 84 . In response to the shortage, there are reports of healthcare workers resorting to procuring their own PPE 85 . The recognition by the WHO and others, that the current global stockpile of PPE is inadequate to meet not only the current need but also future escalating demand 13 has resulted in multiple changes to PPE guidelines published around the world, including PHE, who have been criticised for basing guidance on availability of resources rather than maximising safety of healthcare professionals 86 . The most recent changes, dated 17 th April 2020, include PHE suggesting three options if we run out, including sessional use of PPE, reusing it or using alternatives to standard PPE 87 . The shortage of PPE combined with unclear and changing guidance has resulted in anxiety and confusion for health care workers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Royal College of Surgeons of England found that almost a third (32.5%) of UK surgeons do not have access to enough masks, gowns or eye protection, from a survey of 1,978 surgeons and surgical trainees, and have described a widespread lack of PPE for frontline staff [88] [89] [90] [91] [92] . The RCS recognise that surgeons should not risk their health if they have inadequate PPE 93, 94, 95 . In response to the PPE shortage, ENT UK highlighted that although "FFP3 masks are a precious life-saving and protecting resource, clinical staff are also lifesaving resources and deserve the best protection we can offer" 61 .

The medical work force is at high risk of exposure as well as increased viral infective dose thought to translate to viral load, an independent factor in the severity of the illness. In Italy, health care workers including several surgeons experienced high rates of infection and death due an early lack of PPE 96 , with early deaths, again including surgeons, amongst healthcare workers also reported in the United States of America (USA) and the United Kingdom (UK) 97, 98 . There is good evidence that improved access and use of PPE vastly reduced HCW infections in both Italy and China 99 .

Healthcare resource allocation has political, economic and moral dimensions and in a system where there are limited resources, rationing is inevitable. The National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE) routinely ration treatments based on Quality Adjusted Life Years or QALYs (beneficial health activity) and the lower the cost per QALY, the more efficient the healthcare activity 100 . Rationing of PPE adds a new dimension to modern healthcare practice.
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: We are no longer rationing between patients but between healthcare workers, with organisations having to respond to the changing situation on the ground 66, 77, 78, 101 . Ethical guidance regarding justice within healthcare rationing has often been written by health economists 102 with professional philosophers reluctant to tackle day-to-day policy questions, reflecting the great difficulty in forming ethically sound answers 102 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: There has always been an acceptance that working in a healthcare setting carries a level of personal risk, however, it would seem unreasonable for a healthcare worker to carry out a healthcare activity if there was a high risk of death 103 . In the Ebola crisis 58.3% of health care workers infected with Ebola died in the 3 worst affected countries 104 . In reference to GMC's best practice of ‗making the care of your patient your first concern', Sokol 105 Guidelines for rationing of PPE should follow the scientific evidence and also be morally defensible. A utilitarian approach where the greatest good for the greatest number is promoted, provides a valuable ethical framework and is intuitively scientific as it focuses on the consequences, as being the morally significant entity. It is scientifically justifiable to provide maximal PPE for the higher risk procedures such as AGPs. Some clinicians are better placed to treat COVID-19 patients than others. A utilitarian approach would support protecting these people who could provide the most benefit. Other clinicians may be offered lower levels of protection or their work activities reduced to limit the demand on PPE supplies. To limit certain activities is acceptable, however, to discriminate between clinicians would be a difficult moral calculation and likely to cause considerable distress 106 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: Other ethical considerations such as reciprocity and social worth have also been proposed 106 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: Reciprocity involves giving more protection to clinicians who are most vulnerable due to the higher level of risk that their job entails. For example, Intensivists and Anaesthetists who regularly perform aerosolising procedures may deserve the maximal level of protection not just from a scientific perspective but also a moral one. Social worth is not typically seen as a morally permissible way of allocating resources. In extreme situations, such as a pandemic, where certain roles are essential for the functioning of society it may become permissible.
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: The idea of key workers being allowed to work and receiving special benefits has been derived from this concept.
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: Protecting the vulnerable is another important ethical consideration. People with significant underlying health conditions such as cancer or immune deficiencies have been advised to shield and stay home and lifting lockdown too early will results in excessive deaths 107 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: However, with emerging evidence that black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) groups are at higher risks of severe COVID-19 infection, it is imperative that this is urgently investigated, and guidance is developed to protect those healthcare workers in at risk groups 108 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: A utilitarian perspective using scientific evidence and principles such as social worth, reciprocity and protection of the vulnerable provides a useful framework to make difficult rationing decisions regarding PPE 106 . No one system of allocation will be acceptable to all 109 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: Recent reports of re-using/washing gowns in circumstances of acute shortages of PPE and delays in international shipments 96, 110 bring into sharp focus the difficult decisions that lie ahead. It is imperative decisions and the rationale behind the decisions are transparent and collaborative with all relevant national bodies. This will limit the amount of moral residue and help with rebuilding after the pandemic is over 105 .
body_text.section: The Ethical Dilemma of PPE Rationing

body_text.text: Due to global issues with the supply chain of PPE, many countries have looked to innovative

solutions. An initial focus has been on producing reusable PPE, to reduce both the economic and environmental impact·(28% reduction in natural resource energy consumption and 93% reduction in solid waste generation) 110 Accepted Article theatre equipment has been used, such as orthopaedic helmet systems used for elective arthroplasties, where manifolds were 3D printed and hoods sewed onto the helmet 114 .

There have even been attempts to create electronic personal protective equipment (ePPE) using telemedicine tools to perform electronic medical screening exams, which has the potential to conserve PPE and protect providers while maintaining safe standards for medical screening 115 .

In the short history of this pandemic, medical resources have been rapidly overwhelmed. We are learning more about the novel pathogen SARS-CoV-2 as worldwide research is carried out and shared, including the staff most at riskmales, high BMI, increased age, co-morbidities and those from the Black and Minority Ethnic (BAME) community 118 . National guidelines must keep pace as new information comes to light to protect those most at risk. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

These are unprecedented times where difficult decisions need to be made. However, in the case of rationing PPE, these decisions should be transparent, collaborative, accountable and adaptable as evidence of the pandemic evolves, rather than disguised as guidelines with the minimum level of protection. Changes in guidelines should be communicated honestly and clearly to the public and frontline healthcare professionals without political spin or ambiguity. Making morally sound policies is equally as important as following the scientific evidence to maintain trust, solidarity and a functioning society. Until there is a vaccine or proven treatments available the requirement for surgeons to limit their workload and take sensible precautions is imperative in reducing transmission, flattening the curve, protecting themselves and patients and reducing the death toll.

A study has also shown that SARS-CoV-2 RNA of sewage samples were positive from inlets of the sewage disinfection pool and negative from the outlet of the last sewage disinfection pool, suggested that strict disinfection and hand hygiene could decrease the hospital-associated COVID-19 infection risk of staff in isolation wards 27 . Other than AGPs, the risks of transmission include the fumes released during surgery and contaminated body fluids. Due to the novelty of COVID-19 there is no definitive evidence to quantify the risks of transmission via smoke derived from open or laparoscopic surgery, however there is enough evidence based on previous studies to support steps being undertaken to manage the potential risks 28 . Electrocautery creates particles with the smallest mean size of 0.07 m, with laser tissue ablation generating larger particles with a mean size 0.31 m and the largest particles generated by the ultrasonic (harmonic) scalpel, at 0.35-6.5 m 29 . The smaller the particles, the further they travel. Smaller particles are more chemically based, but as the particulate This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. Accepted Article matter increases in size, it poses more of a biological hazard, acting as a vector for pathogen transmission, with larger particles traveling up to 1 meter from the operative field 30 . The majority of smoke evacuation and filtration modes facilitate capture of particles above 0.01 m. As the SARS-CoV-2 aerodynamic size is described in the range of 0.06-0.15 m 29,31 , the use of devices with smoke evacuation filters theoretically reduce local inoculation. Previous work has confirmed viral content (papillomavirus & HIV) within surgical smoke 32,33 and documented operator contraction of a papilloma virus using carbon dioxide laser 34 . There are also risks of transmission due to urine spillage and aerosolisation in open and minimally invasive urological interventions, with Ling et al. reporting persistence of SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid in urine 35 . Although disease transmission of COVID-19 through urine has not yet been demonstrated, The European Association of Urology Robotic Urology Section (ERUS) stated urethral or ureteral catheterisation during laparoscopic and robotic procedures should be treated with caution 36 . The British Association of Urological Surgeons (BAUS) describe the risk of operator contamination from urine splash as minimal and state aerosol risks are more significant from patients coughing during intimate procedures e.g. catheterisation, or following intubation/extubation. Furthermore, SARS-CoV-2 RNA has also been identified in faeces 37 . Many studies have found that SARS-CoV-1 RNA could be detected in plasma, since the first report on April 10, 2003 38-40 . Overall, 78% of patients had detectable viral RNA in the first week of their illness 41 in line with MERS-CoV 42 and SARS-CoV-2 43 . Due to the risk of asymptomatic carriage and the presence of virus in the blood the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the American Association of Blood Banks (AABB) have published rapid risk assessments regarding blood safety during the pandemic. The ECDC implied a precautionary deferral of donation of blood and cells for 21 days after possible exposure to a confirmed patient or anyone who returned from Wuhan, Chinaapplying the approach used for SARS-CoV-1 and MERS-CoV 44 . Types of personal protective equipment Recommendations made by the WHO regarding the use of PPE in the management of patients who have or are suspected to have COVID-19 in community and hospital settings This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. Accepted Article have evolved alongside developing evidence regarding transmission 13 . The standard PPE guidance by Public Health England (PHE) for healthcare workers involved in the direct care of patients within one meter with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 include; disposable apron, gloves, a fluid repellent surgical mask and eye protection comprising either goggles or a face shield 45 . When working in high risk units (e.g. ITU/HDU/A&E Resus/Wards with Non Invasive Ventilation or Continuous Positive Airway Pressure ventilation/Operating theatres/Endoscopy units) or in theatre where AGPs are being undertaken, then a respirator (N99 or FFP3 equivalent, which can be either valved or unvalved) is recommended instead of a surgical mask along with a fluid repellent long gown 46 and full-face shield or visor 13,45,46 (Figure 2). PHE are in support of full PPE in relation to AGP's conducted in ANY patient i.e. given the high asymptomatic carrier rate reported in some populations of 16-50% 47 the assumption should be made that all patients, regardless of symptoms, are COVID-19 positive. Respirator masks are categorised according to their ability to filter fine particles in the scale of 0.01-1 m in size according to the EU defined Filtering Face Piece (FFP) Scale, whereas SARS-CoV-2 measures 0.07-0.09 m in diameter on electron microscopy studies 48 . Most specialty guidelines recommend avoidance of AGPs wherever possible but if required full PPE is advised. The British Association for Paediatric Otolaryngology & ENT UK in conjunction with the National Tracheostomy Safety Project (NTSP) outline measures for tracheostomies in an effort to reduce potential risks. The documents highlight the need to balance the need for a tracheostomy versus the potential risks to both the patient and staff 54 . Many further publications relating to changes in ENT practice have been published 55-60 . The British Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons (BAOMS) guidance recommends full PPE for all close face to face contact with patients, not only treatment but also examination, until the current trajectory has flattened 61,62 , which can be applied to other surgical specialties such as Plastic Surgery and ENT which involve examination and treatment of the head and neck area when managing trauma or cancer near the aerodigestive tract 63,64,65 .

A doctor's duty of care creates an implicit and explicit social contract with both patients and society as a whole, to care and treat patients despite a degree of personal risk 102 . PHE and other public health bodies have suggested a minimum level of PPE for specific interactions with COVID-19 suspected or positive patients (Figure 1) and when combined with variations in guidance from different national and international bodies with differing local interpretations of guidance and poor communication have understandably created a sense of fear amongst healthcare professionals.

FIGREF5.text: There has been a huge focus both in the NHS itself and the National Press regarding personal protective equipment. Lessons from China showed that high healthcare worker infection rates were only improved once PPE was adequate. As a nation, we have had time to plan for this pandemic compared to others less fortunate countries such as Italy and China, where relatively large numbers of healthcare workers succumbed to COVID-19. Such planning has been widely criticised in the scientific press 116 and in recent days there have been wellreported critical shortages of PPE in the UK including gowns and masks. After missing out on an opportunity to join the European Union (EU) joint procurement scheme to bulkpurchase PPE, there is an ever more urgent need to secure and coordinate supply chains 117 . Boris Johnson has recently appointed a PPE 'Tsar', former London Olympics chief executive Paul Deigthon, to coordinate, source and boost manufacturing of protective equipment needed to protect NHS staff. The medical work force is at high risk of exposure as well as increased viral load and although there is a need to balance limited supplies with staff and patient safety, this should not leave the healthcare professionals treating patients with inadequate PPE. The BMA, RCS and Royal College of Nursing have all spoken out saying their members should not be in this position.
